name: yunlong jiao
professional_summary: I am currently a machine learning scientist at Amazon Alexa, working on building AI assistant that is able to replicate human intelligence. I am passionate about applied AI research that drives tangible impact for products and services. With over 5 years of post-PhD experience in the field of ML/AI, I possess strong skills in model development and performance evaluation, and am proficient in Python and deep learning frameworks. While successfully incubating and delivering multiple projects at Amazon, I am involved in all phases of the development cycle – from building proof of concept to delivering minimum viable products and scaling up production. I have experience in supervising master’s theses and research internships, as well as coaching and mentoring junior team members.

Department of Mathematics, University of Paris-Saclay
Department of Mathematics, University of Science & Technology of China

responsibilities: Leading research on bias mitigation technologies in NLP to enhance fairness while preserving user privacy.
Building and deploying ML solutions in creating unified user experiences for Alexa Shopping across different devices.
Working in cross-functional teams, overseeing prototype to production, and communicating results with stakeholders.
Supervising research internships and coaching and mentoring junior team members.

Leading Oxford research in a multi-organizational project (involving organizations in the UK and EU) and developing novel methods for longitudinal modelling of complex disease using multi-modal data integration.
Supervising master’s theses in the Department of Statistics.
My PhD work contributed novel ML methods and advanced scientific discoveries in biology and cancer research.
My research focus was kernel methods and representation learning of non-tabular data, such as rank data and graphs.
My research outputs significantly improved prediction of breast cancer survival using genetic data, and guided interpretable biomarker discovery with the help of biological networks.
I had published multiple first-authored papers in top ML conferences and journals (3 at ICML and 1 at IEEE TPAMI) and developed open-source toolkits.

A few colleagues and I participated, and finally placed 2nd, in the DREAM Toxicogenetics Challenge, a Kaggle-style community competition in data science that is aimed to advance computational methods in biology.
Proposed a data pipeline to process large-scale unstructured machinery performance data and built a model to predict failure state for automated immunoassay analyzers.
Demonstrated how maintenance efficiency can be greatly improved for one of Roche’s core hardware products.
My work had a direct impact on strengthening customer trust, and the innovative solution was patented by Roche.
